documentType: search warrant application and affidavit with attached indictment
summary: This document is an FBI Special Agent's affidavit in support of a search warrant for Jeffrey Epstein's New York residence at 9 East 71st Street. It details the investigation into sex trafficking of minors and includes the sealed indictment against Epstein, alleging a pattern of abuse from 2002-2005 at his New York and Palm Beach homes.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The financier accused of sex trafficking and conspiracy for sexually abusing dozens of minor girls at his New York and Palm Beach residences from at least 2002 to 2005.

persons.name: Barbara Moses
persons.context: The judge before whom the search warrant affidavit is sworn and who is requested to issue the warrant.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: The U.S. Attorney who signed the indictment against Jeffrey Epstein.

connections.description: Epstein directed Employee-1, a New York-based employee, to communicate with victims via phone to arrange sexual encounters at the New York Residence.
Epstein arranged for Employee-2 to contact victims to schedule encounters at the Palm Beach Residence, including calls made from New York.
Employee-3, an assistant, was responsible for scheduling sexual encounters with minor victims for Epstein at the Palm Beach Residence.
Epstein sexually abused Victim-1 on multiple occasions at the New York residence when she was under 18, and she later recruited other girls for him.
Epstein repeatedly sexually abused Minor Victim-1 at the New York Residence over years, paid her, and encouraged her to recruit other girls.
Epstein repeatedly sexually abused Minor Victim-2 at the Palm Beach Residence over years, paid her, and encouraged her to recruit other girls.
Epstein repeatedly sexually abused Minor Victim-3 at the Palm Beach Residence over years, paid her, and encouraged her to recruit other girls.

events.title: Indictment of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: A grand jury in the Southern District of New York returned an indictment charging Jeffrey Epstein with sex trafficking of minors and sex trafficking conspiracy.

events.title: Beginning of Alleged Abuse Pattern
events.description: The indictment alleges Jeffrey Epstein began enticing and recruiting dozens of minor girls to engage in sex acts with him at his New York and Palm Beach residences.

events.title: Period of Alleged Sexual Abuse in New York
events.description: Epstein allegedly sexually abused multiple minor girls at his New York Residence, with victims as young as 14, in a pattern involving 'massages' that escalated to sex acts.

events.title: Employee-1 Calls Minor Victim-1
events.description: Employee-1, on behalf of Epstein, placed a telephone call to Minor Victim-1 to schedule an appointment for paid sex acts at the New York Residence.

events.title: Employee-2 Calls Minor Victims
events.description: Employee-2, on behalf of Epstein, placed telephone calls to Minor Victim-2 and Minor Victim-3 to schedule appointments for paid sex acts at the Palm Beach Residence.

events.title: Property Transfer to Maple, Inc.
events.description: Ownership of 9 East 71st Street was transferred from Nine East 71st Street Corporation to Maple, Inc., a U.S. Virgin Islands entity, for $10, suggesting Epstein maintained control.

locations: 9 East 71st Street, New York, New York (Epstein's New York Residence)
Palm Beach Residence, Palm Beach, Florida (Epstein's Florida estate)
Southern District of New York (jurisdiction for legal proceedings)
U.S. Virgin Islands (where Maple, Inc. is registered)
keyFacts: The FBI sought a warrant to search and photograph the interior of Jeffrey Epstein's 9 East 71st Street mansion to corroborate victim accounts of sexual abuse that occurred there from 2002-2005.
Epstein was indicted on July 2, 2019, for sex trafficking conspiracy and sex trafficking of minors, specifically for abusing dozens of girls as young as 14.

The indictment describes a systematic scheme where Epstein paid victims hundreds of dollars in cash for sexual encounters and incentivized them to recruit other minor girls, creating a 'vast network' of victims.

Epstein controlled the New York residence through corporate entities (Nine East 71st Street Corp. and later Maple, Inc.), with a 2011 transfer for $10 indicating a sham transaction to maintain ownership.

The affidavit reveals that a key victim (Victim-1) provided detailed descriptions of the mansion's interior, which investigators believed remained structurally unchanged since the mid-2000s, making photographic evidence valuable for corroboration.
